Award.AwardTitle: Novel Optical Hosts: Chemistry, Single Crystal Growth and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This project develops techniques to grow large single crystals of important materials for use in optics that are otherwise difficult to prepare and study. Many of the efforts focus on a fundamental study of fields such as new laser materials. These materials will add to the basic scientific understanding of new laser applications, new display technologies and new detector science. The primary support will be for the training of graduate students particularly those working toward the Ph.D. degree. They are being trained to perform research in crystal growth, characterization and properties of new materials for optical applications, an area that is generally underdeveloped in the US. Student interactions with industrial and national laboratory collaborators will be supported. The broader impacts of this work will enhance the expertise of the next generation of materials and expand the capacity of US researchers in optics and lasers.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, this project employs the use of hydrothermal fluids, namely aqueous phases between 500-700 C and 1-2kbar for fundamental explorations of new solids. These conditions provide a unique medium for the exploratory growth of new materials, particularly in the form of large, high quality single crystals. This program focuses in particular, on single crystals that can serve as hosts for optical applications including lasing, up-conversion and scintillation. The emphasis is on metal oxides and halides that can be selectively doped with optically active ions. The goal is to discover and identify new phases that can be made in this unique reaction medium, and to study their structural and spectroscopic properties. There are three broad thrust areas under investigation, the novel chemistry of beryl-based oxides, the host chemistry of vanadates, and the fundamental exploratory chemistry of metal tantalates and niobates. In all cases, new structural types will be sought and their subsequent spectroscopic and optical properties will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project employed the hydrothermal method to grow a wide range of new materials as high quality single crystals. The synthetic technique uses water heated well above its boiling point under pressure (500-700˚C and 1-3 kbar) as a reaction medium, and this turns out to be an excellent way to synthesize new single crystal materials. The method is very old, dating from 1870, but was largely neglected in the last 50 years or so. This project and several previous NSF awards resurrected the detailed study of the technique and demonstrated its usefulness in the preparation of new materials. This project initially focused on the use of a range of oxyanion building blocks to serve as hosts for optical applications such as laser hosts and particularly, nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals.  We examined routes to acentric crystals for NLO applications with special focus on the visible and UV regimes. This work continued to build on work from a previous NSF award that led to the development of several important NLO crystals that steadily made their way into the commercial sector, and now form the basis of a new startup company growing single crystals for solid state UV laser manufacture. In this project we extended this work to new regions of the periodic table and generalized the approach to new acentric crystals. This work was quite successful and provided an extensive range of new acentric solids with suitable bandgaps for visible and UV NLO activity. 

As this project evolved we also realized that many of the concepts involved in designing and building acentric solids could also be applied directly to other important types of compounds such ferroics and especially magnetic materials. This particularly includes frustrated magnetic solids that can display emergent non-classical behavior such as spin liquids and spin glasses. Thus we prepared a series of exciting new single crystal materials with trigonal symmetry with exceptionally complex magnetic behavior that is a function of the frustrated nature of the crystals. Tetrahedral and trigonal oxyanion building blocks like vanadates, carbonates and germanates that served so well in acentric crystal formation are also ideal for imparting magnetic frustration in crystalline lattices. This realization opened the door for the growth of a wide range of new magnetic materials. More importantly it is even beginning to suggest the formation of quantum materials including long sought phases like quantum spin liquids and topological conductors. One vitally important aspect of this chemistry is the fact that our synthetic approach uses relatively low temperatures compared to classical crystal growth methods (i.e. melt and flux growth at 1200-2500˚C). This means that the crystals we grow have two important qualities. They contain minimal lattice defects and little if any site disorder among the metal ion building blocks. These two characteristics are absolutely essential for the study of emergent non-classical quantum phenomena.

The intellectual merits of this project are several-fold. Our approach to the rational development of acentric single crystals leads to a much deeper understanding of how to design and grow acentric crystals. This is allowing us to systematically improve the optical properties of NLO crystals. Another important intellectual breakthrough is the realization that the critical factors leading to acentric crystals are very similar to those that lead to ferroic and frustrated magnetic materials. This will hopefully teach us to design and synthesize new forms of matter like multiferroics and frustrated magnets. This exciting chemistry might even provide us access to the biggest prize of all, namely quantum materials such as quantum spin liquids.

The projects had a number of broader impacts. It was responsible for the support of a number of graduate students, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Most of the grad students on the project successfully obtained their Ph.D. degrees and went on to significant careers. These students received training in the design and growth of large single crystals for physical applications. The formal study of single crystals growth is woefully lacking the in the United States so these students are filling an important niche. The rapid development of magnetic materials over the course of this project opened up opportunities with new outside collaborators. For example we now have a very rich and active collaboration with Oak Ridge National Lab wherein we provide single crystals for detailed neutron and magnetic studies with them. Also the work continues to generate commercial and technology transfer opportunities. We have a number of patents as the result of work on this and earlier projects, and several of these are now licensed to private companies with some even forming the basis of a new startup company.
